utterances: Go ahead, Ezra.
This is actually interesting because what you have in undecided voters are there are a couple types, right?
There are what you can call - they are nonpartisan undecided which are people who don't like the Republican party, they don't like the Democratic party.
So sort of every year, they vote for -you know they would be Perot voters a couple of years ago...
Or Ron Paul voters.
Or Ron Paul voters.
Well, a little bit less.
So he's a bit more marginal than Perot was.
But what you also have - and this interesting because you don't get them at the primaries - is voters who are dissatisfied with their party's choice.
These are not voters who persist in being undecided or being swing or being confused from election to election.
They are voters who that election that they were involved in the primaries they supported as Bonnie did, say Hillary Clinton.
Their candidate did not win and so until fairly late in the game, they tend to be undecided, in part, as a result of that.
Again, you know you can't use the aggregate data to predict any one person.
Where Bonnie will go, will have a lot to do with, you know, I guess what Joe Biden says tonight or in a week or whatever.
But in general, they break very, very heavily towards whichever party they voted for in the primary.
That tends to be the scenario of it - that there is a lot of lingering mistrust of the candidate who they did not support in the primary.
But at the end of the day, the party affiliation tends to be stronger than the (unintelligible).
Because frankly, if you were a Hillary Clinton supporter, Barack Obama is much closer to everything you apparently believe than John McCain is.

I mean there's literally not issue where the two of them - where John McCain stacks up better at Hillary Clinton than Barack Obama does, but you still may not feel great about him given the biases you picked up and beliefs you picked up and you know sort of an anger you picked up during the primary.
And remember the criticisms your candidate had against him.
Exactly.
Very much.
I was going to ask you that.
I was going to ask you that.
So you knew it was about you.
And like - what - did people, I don't know, see you in the elevator and start singing?
I mean, what the heck?
What was that like for you?
She says that her secretary didn't tell her about it.
Oh, boy.
But anyway, here's an email.
This is from Alice.
I am an undecided voter in California.
I'm not sure if I should vote for Barack Obama or Cynthia McKinney.
California will almost certainly go to Obama so I'm considering giving a vote to a third party that I also believe and hopes to give it more attention and power.
If I live in the states where the chances of McCain where winning were tighter, I would vote for Obama."" So this is a strategic vote.
Right.
I wouldn't call that undecided.
It's a very tactical move.
Here's one from Jeremy in Aloha, Oregon.

I don't know who to vote for because neither the candidates have explained what they're really going to accomplish now that the Bush administration has allowed all of our capital to bail out Wall Street.
You know I have to say, I mean this does get into what you're saying about people paying attention to other things.

I am never quite sure how to take the thing that the problem of candidates are not offering any ideas or any - what the candidates are offering are a lot of ideas that they probably will not be able to implement because Congress is biased towards obstruction and so forth.
But the idea that what they don't have or of a lot of plans for what they're going to do has always struck me as very odd and I tend to think it's a way that folks...
These are people who've never been to either of their websites.
But it's not even that.
I think people don't trust.
And I think you're hearing that from Bonnie in there, too.
I don't think that they - it's a little bit hard to put into words, I think, the fact that the political system fails us.
It fails us over and over and over again.
It is rotted to its core.
I think you have a situation right now where people now.
I mean you have global warming coming in 30 or 40 or 50 years with terrible consequences.
You have a health-care system that will break the back of the federal budget within 25 years.
And most people would tell you is anything going to be done?
No, it's pretty hard.
I mean there's something broken, and I think people sense it.
And so when all these folks you know year after year run and say they're going to get all this done, I think when they say they don't have a plan, they don't mean they don't have specifics.
I always sort of get the sense that they mean they don't actually have a plan of how are we going to get this done.
It's like the old joke about economist assume a can opener.

You can't assume your policy is going to go through and it's very hard for these folks to sort of demonstrate why they will be more effective in their actions than will all the candidates, seemingly qualified individuals who ran for this office before them.
We're talking with Ezra Klein of the American Prospect about his op-ed in the Los Angeles Times called ""Undecided Voters."" You're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And let's go to James.
James with us from Corona in California.
Yes.
Hi, James.
Go ahead, please.
Well I'm a true independent.
I'm one feels that government should be run like a business.
The beginning of any campaign, you've got either candidate pandering to their base, only telling them what they want to hear.
Very few people are very objective about things.

So the longer this takes, the more things filter out to a point where they will hopefully answer exactly what their economic policies are, what their international policies are, what their strategies are, what their strengths are.
And in this day and age - I was on an aircraft courier in the Cuban missile crisis and trust me, it was extremely scary.

I would like to find out if either one of the candidates have the ability and the willpower to push the button should everything fall because there is a window in that sort of activity of maybe two-and-a-half minutes that you have to have the guts to call a first strike or else all of your first-strike capabilities are taken out.
James, I think we can all hope and pray that we don't ever discover whichever presidential candidate wins has the nerve to do that.
Well, that's one of the aspects.
The other thing is who's going to run the government like a business as opposed to pandering to either side.
And how do you make your decision, James?

Well, I will make my decision in the final debate of which candidate has the balls, basically, to tell the American people exactly what their economic policies are and do they have the nerve to defend the country in extreme circumstances.
James, I don't mean to anticipate the future, but you may be disappointed.
The debates thus far have not answered those questions.
Pardon?
You may be disappointed.
We've not heard those answers in the debate.
Anyway, thanks very much for the phone call.
Well, that could possibly be true, but it's the one who filters out to finally who's forced to telling the more specific truth.
I think the more time it takes, the more people will get pressed to the wall to answer those questions.
All right, James.
Thanks very much for the call.
The fact that Republicans don't have James solidly on their right now is real evidence of the trouble John McCain is in.
Because you listened to what he just said, right?
Government run like a business and who - what did he say - have the cahones to nuke someone?
That's not the sort of metric that you generally get we're going to elect an Illinois liberal or like the Massachusetts democrat.
But I do think what you are saying is a certain level of ideological ensemble(ph), a feeling of being unsettled.
There's so much failure among these folks right now.
There's so much failure in what the Republicans have done that would control the country in the past couple of years.
And a lot of people who I think would normally - you know basically know where they lean are having trouble coming to grips with what that would mean again.

And this would argue against - you cite a political scientist by the name of Paul Lazarsfeld from the 1940s who argued the campaigns are essentially over before they began that in fact what the campaigns do is accomplish the same thing that the chemicals do in the photographic process where they bring out the picture, but they can only bring out the picture that is there already.
There's a template that's established and James will vote Republican.
I don't know that James will...
The James of the world.
Well, what he would say is that events matter, right?
What he would say is that it's not that it started before.
It's not about party affiliations.
It's more complicated than that and that events matter.
And so in part of the photograph of the election would be this financial crisis, right?
This is not something created by either - despite what the two of them may say - neither Barack Obama nor John McCain - I'm very bipartisan here - created the financial crisis.
But that was a serious definitional event in the election.
And a month ago, John McCain was ahead.
I feel like people are forgetting it's a month and a half ago.
Then this happens, this is a sort of thing that really, really tends to militate towards Democrats and now Barack Obama is ahead.
That's part of what that political scientist was talking about.
That you know we like to say that politics are about campaigns, and we do that in large part because the media likes to cover politics as being about campaigns.
(Unintelligible) control, they take out ads, etc.
But frankly, politics is really in large part about events.
Candidates tend to win when they are incumbents and the economy is doing well.
They lose if they are incumbents and the economy is doing poorly.
And I think similarly on foreign policy, they lose when the foreign policy situation is unsettled and scary, and they're judged to have done a poor job and they win when that's not true.

And I think what you're saying for Republicans for McCain with people like James is simply that people feel unsettled with Republicans and the election is breaking in much way you would have predicted a year ago if you had know about a financial crisis.
We'll end with this email from Thomas in Salt Lake City.
I'm an undecided voter and not uninformed.
I listen to NPR.
I'm undecided because I believe I cannot know what the best option is for the whole nation and I don't think anybody does.
I have to believe that to take a strong stand on any decisions, I need to understand all sides thoroughly, something I believe no one can.
So I view people with strong opinions and unmovable in their stances as mostly under-informed.
Well, in any case, Ezra Klein, a man of strong opinions and informed, thanks very much for your time today.
Thank you.
Ezra Klein is associate editor of the American Prospect magazine.
His op-ed appeared in Sunday's Los Angeles Times and he joined us here in Studio 3A.
We'll be with you from Roanoke, Virginia, tomorrow.
This is Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan.
And now we turn to a story of love, friendship and music.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SUITE: JUDY BLUE EYES"")
(Singing) It's getting to the point where I'm no fun anymore.
Half a century ago, singer-songwriter Stephen Stills and Judy Collins fell in love.
The romantic relationship only lasted two years, but the imprint of one on the other endured.
After the couple split, Stephen joined the now legendary group Crosby, Stills & Nash.
With emotions fresh from the breakup, he wrote what would become one of the group's biggest hits and what many call the best rock breakup song ever, ""Suite: Judy Blue Eyes.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SUITE: JUDY BLUE EYES"")
(Singing) I am yours.
You are mine.
You are what you are.
(Singing) You make it hard (laughter).
And Judy Collins's career also blossomed.
She was one of the most popular live acts of the 1960s and one of the female folk artists who defined the era with hits like this.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""BOTH SIDES NOW"")
